title: My Resume
text:
BS in Data Science Winter 2027 Current Position: Student Dispatch Team Lead


Python, R, Chemistry/Biology/Biochemistry





BYU-Idaho Rexburg, ID 3.7 GPA



Rexburg, ID 3.8 GPA 33 ACT score Madison High School Swim Team (Fall of 2019 and 2020) State Qualifier in 2019 and 2020 seasons MVP of 2020 Madison swim team






BYU-I Rexburg, ID Operated independently and with coworkers to: Respond to phone calls and assist people in resolving concerns Watched camera footage in relation to legal incidents Direct radio traffic of campus security personnel Promoted to Student Team Lead September 8 2025 Trained new student dispatchers in addition to previous duties



Jeppesen Farms
Rexburg, ID Put in up to 18 hours a day for two weeks in 2019 and 2020 excluding Sundays Operated heavy machinery Removed rotten potatoes, dirt clods, and rocks from good potatoes



Rexburg Rapids
Rexburg, ID
Lifeguard (2017-2021) Ensured safety around the pool and was first aid/CPR/AED trained Swim Coach (2017-2021) Coached several kids, some later placed highly at State level competitions Swim Teacher (2020-2021) Taught kids safety skills in and around the water and how to improve swimming ability



Gravity Factory
Rexburg, ID Verified patrons followed rules and stayed safe while also demonstrating acrobatic skills to patrons



Cold Stone
Rexburg, ID Ensured cleanliness and great customer service with a team of up to three people




Served as a missionary for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints from May 2022 - April 2024. Provided service to my community, taught people about Jesus Christ, and mantained a demanding schedule.
Southern Colorado Spent 6 months focusing on teaching people the gospel.
Southeastern Idaho 18 months of service spent working at food banks, temple, libraries, and many other locations who needed volunteers.

title: Introduction
text:
Submission
Each problem group asks a series of questions. This assignment consists of two submissions:

After completing the questions below, open the Module 01 Assessment Quiz in Canvas and enter your answers to these questions there.
After completing and submitting the quiz, save this Colab notebook as a GitHub Gist (You’ll need to create a GitHub account for this), by selecting Save a copy as a GitHub Gist from the File menu above.
In Canvas, open the Module 01 Assessment GitHub Gist assignment and paste the GitHub Gist URL for this notebook. Then submit that assignment.

title: Introduction
text:
Problem Group 1
For the questions in this group, you’ll work with the Netflix Movies Dataset found at this url: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byui-cse/cse450-course/master/data/netflix_titles.csv

Question 1
Load the dataset into a Pandas data frame and determine what data type is used to store the release_year feature.

import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byui-cse/cse450-course/master/data/netflix_titles.csv")


df.info()
print("release_year is stored as an int64 data type")

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
RangeIndex: 6234 entries, 0 to 6233
Data columns (total 12 columns):
 #   Column        Non-Null Count  Dtype 
---  ------        --------------  ----- 
 0   show_id       6234 non-null   int64 
 1   type          6234 non-null   object
 2   title         6234 non-null   object
 3   director      4265 non-null   object
 4   cast          5664 non-null   object
 5   country       5758 non-null   object
 6   date_added    6223 non-null   object
 7   release_year  6234 non-null   int64 
 8   rating        6224 non-null   object
 9   duration      6234 non-null   object
 10  listed_in     6234 non-null   object
 11  description   6234 non-null   object
dtypes: int64(2), object(10)
memory usage: 584.6+ KB
release_year is stored as an int64 data type




Question 2
Filter your dataset so it contains only TV Shows. How many of those TV Shows were rated TV-Y7?

shows = df.query('type == "TV Show"')
tv_y7 = shows.query("rating == 'TV-Y7'")
shows['rating'].value_counts()

rating

68

dtype: int64




Question 3
Further filter your dataset so it only contains TV Shows released between the years 2000 and 2009 inclusive. How many of those shows were rated TV-Y7?

after2000 = tv_y7.query('release_year >= 2000')
target = after2000.query('release_year<= 2009')
target.info()

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
Index: 4 entries, 4528 to 6117
Data columns (total 12 columns):
 #   Column        Non-Null Count  Dtype 
---  ------        --------------  ----- 
 0   show_id       4 non-null      int64 
 1   type          4 non-null      object
 2   title         4 non-null      object
 3   director      0 non-null      object
 4   cast          4 non-null      object

 8   rating        4 non-null      object

 11  description   4 non-null      object

title: Introduction
text:
Problem Group 2
For the questions in this group, you’ll work with the Cereal Dataset found at this url: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byui-cse/cse450-course/master/data/cereal.csv

Question 4
After importing the dataset into a pandas data frame, determine the median amount of protein in cereal brands manufactured by Kelloggs. (mfr code “K”)

df2 = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byui-cse/cse450-course/master/data/cereal.csv")
kel = df2.query("mfr == 'K'")
kel.protein.median()

3.0




Question 5
In order to comply with new government regulations, all cereals must now come with a “Healthiness” rating. This rating is calculated based on this formula:
healthiness = (protein + fiber) / sugar
Create a new healthiness column populated with values based on the above formula.
Then, determine the median healthiness value for only General Mills cereals (mfr = “G”), rounded to two decimal places.

df2['healthiness'] = (df2['protein'] + df2['fiber'])/df2['sugars']
genmills = df2.query('mfr == "G"')
genmills.healthiness.median()

0.475

title: Introduction
text:
Problem Group 3
For the questions in this group, you’ll work with the Titanic Dataset found at this url: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byui-cse/cse450-course/master/data/titanic.csv

Question 6
After loading the dataset into a pandas DataFrame, create a new column called NameGroup that contains the first letter of the passenger’s surname in lower case.
Note that in the dataset, passenger’s names are provided in the Name column and are listed as:
Surname, Given names
For example, if a passenger’s Name is Braund, Mr. Owen Harris, the NameGroup column should contain the value b.
Then count how many passengers have a NameGroup value of k.

titan = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byui-cse/cse450-course/master/data/titanic.csv")
titan.info()

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
RangeIndex: 891 entries, 0 to 890
Data columns (total 12 columns):
 #   Column       Non-Null Count  Dtype  
---  ------       --------------  -----  
 0   PassengerId  891 non-null    int64  
 1   Survived     891 non-null    object 
 2   Pclass       891 non-null    int64  
 3   Name         891 non-null    object 
 4   Sex          891 non-null    object 
 5   Age          714 non-null    float64
 6   SibSp        891 non-null    int64  
 7   Parch        891 non-null    int64  
 8   Ticket       891 non-null    object 
 9   Fare         891 non-null    float64
 10  Cabin        204 non-null    object 
 11  Embarked     889 non-null    object 
dtypes: float64(2), int64(4), object(6)
memory usage: 83.7+ KB




titan['NameGroup'] = titan['Name'].astype(str).str[0].str.lower()
k = titan.query("NameGroup == 'k'")
titan['NameGroup'].value_counts()
k.NameGroup.value_counts()








count


NameGroup





k
28




dtype: int64
